children.subject: Both are names for the same thing.

I haven't taken them together, but a portion of CS188 builds on Bayes' theorem which is taught in the second half of CS70. For students without prior probability experience it may be new and unintuitive, but reading ahead in CS70 can fix that.

I've TA'd for both. and I've seen students who take both concurrently. (I don't know how they did / can't comment on their experience.)

As the anon above notes, the way in which 188 depends on 70 is primarily the probability part, which is the basis for a substantial part of 188, especially in the MT2 material. (At a rough estimate, 80% of the problems on MT2 are probability-related.) 70 teaches this material in the second half of the course, which is after 188 has started covering the topics.

Of course, it's always possible to self-study the material, and 188 spends some effort in helping students review the prerequisite material (because even among students who did take 70, some have forgotten lots of the key concepts). 

And I'm always emphasized to my students that the 188's MT2 really requires students to be super-comfortable (i.e. fast) with working with probability (e.g. doing Bayesian inference), and just a 70-level familiarity with probability is likely not sufficient, so all students would be spending effort in this area anyway.

The concept of expectation (taught after probability in 70) is also useful in 188 in order to understand how we calculate utilities (MT1), analyze MDPs (MT1), and calculate VPIs (MT2), although 188 kind of skims over the details of how expectation is used.

In summary, I wouldn't ignore 70 as a prereq for 188, but this is probably doable with sufficient extra effort. Reading ahead in the 70 notes certainly helps to learn/understand the concepts, but spending time working on 188 problems would likely help more in building familiarity.

For a subset of some opinions of other students answering the same question.

https://www.facebook.com/groups/631097886985088/permalink/747604238667785/

https://www.facebook.com/groups/631097886985088/permalink/701382446623298/ (Note that Dibyo's comment no longer applies)

https://www.facebook.com/groups/berkeleycs/permalink/580910152003862/

I would personally say no no. First half of CS188 is very similar to some parts of CS 70. For example, understanding/analyzing how Stable Marriage Algorithm runs is a pretty import indirect skill for CS188 algorithms (A*, minmax, CSP, Markov etc...). Also, the second half of CS188 depends on probs from CS70. I don't think it's a good combo. The question "whether it's doable" is misleading because everything is doable with enough effort. But imho this particular one is too much and would be detrimental to learning experience.
+1 I also did this and it was totally fine.

I did both last semester. It went fine! They had no overlap that I can think of, except for basic probability rules (Bayes' Law, etc.), and maybe a little bit of stuff about Markov chains. There's no issue taking them together.
I took them together last semester and I had no problem.

Nicole, I think that the official advice is a very loud "DO NOT DO THIS" for taking 188 without having taken 70, especially when we are talking about our majors. 

I think that any student who violates prerequisites without instructor permission ethically needs to promise to not attend office hours with any difficulties regarding the material, not to be in a study group with any student who has taken the prerequisites, and not to ask questions on either piazza or in discussion section. It is incredibly rude to distort the learning experience for other students because the student couldn't be bothered to actually be prepared. It makes life harder for the TAs as well. Yes, there are a small fraction of students who can do this without causing a disruption. Those students also shouldn't need to ask any questions or work with anyone. For a larger fraction, it only *seems* to work but the students have gaps and holes in their understanding. Another group muddles through, knowing that they are confused, but just counting on others to help them get through it. There is a reason why lower division material is lower division --- to make sure that students master it and have a solid foundation to build upon. For every student for whom it makes sense to skip a prerequisite, there are a lot more who are caught up in an immature subculture of fake bravado and showing off. This should not be encouraged at all.

Hi Prof. Sahai, I appreciate your reasoning, but I do respectfully disagree. It really depends on the student. For motivated students who have maybe done competition math and algorithmic coding challenges in high school, this should hopefully not constrain them. And there are lots of these kind of students here, I would not say it's a very small fraction. I have taken cs 70 and 188, and the 188 probability (conditioning, total prob, bayes) is just stuff I learned in high school. More so, some of these prereqs are outdated and don't make much logical sense. For example for 189 it was a prereq in the past to take 188, but now that's gone and for a good reason.

Is 16A not a pre-requisite for 16B? I seem to remember a post where you, Professor Sahai, tell students to do Math 54+16B without taking 16A, despite content from 16A being needed in 16B. Why is this the exception, despite 188 using similar levels of content from 70 as 16B does from 16A?
I think that might be because Math 54 has a lot of redundancy with 16A but doesn't teach for example SVD which is in 16B? So, for people who have taken 54 and 110, 16A is kind of a waste of time

Taking 188 without 70

I really want to take CS188 next semester (my 2nd semester of junior year) in order to take 288/89 by my final semester in Berkeley, but I still haven't taken CS70. Given that I'm taking CS70 next semester, would it be fine to take the classes concurrently? Is the class heavily reliant on 70 or can I learn the necessary material over break? If anyone has been in a similar situation, please share. Any input is appreciated.

history.content: Has anyone taken these courses together? Thoughts? Thank you!
history.subject: CS 188 with CS 70
